support_summary: Exportin 1 (XPO1) is a nuclear export receptor that can directly bind to TDP-43 to mediate its transport out of the nucleus. However, this appears to be a redundant pathway, as inhibition of XPO1 alone is not sufficient to prevent TDP-43 export.

functions.cellular_process: Exportin 1 (XPO1), a major nuclear export receptor, recognizes and binds to proteins containing a leucine-rich nuclear export signal (NES), mediating their transport from the nucleus to the cytoplasm.
functions.effect_description: The nuclear export of TDP-43 is facilitated, contributing to the cytoplasmic pool of the protein, though this pathway is considered redundant.
biological_consequence: XPO1 overexpression → Enhanced binding to TDP-43 Nuclear Export Signal (NES) → Increased nuclear export of TDP-43 → Cytoplasmic accumulation → Increased risk of aggregation & cellular toxicity.
specific_effects: Pharmacological inhibition or depletion of XPO1 has little to no effect on the subcellular localization of TDP-43, suggesting it is not the primary exporter. [7]
Overexpression of XPO1, as well as other exportins like XPO7 and NXF1, is sufficient to promote the nuclear export of TDP-43. [7]
TDP-43 likely exits the nucleus via redundant pathways and/or passive diffusion through the nuclear pore complex. [3, 20]

evidence.paper_title: TDP43 nuclear export and neurodegeneration in models of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis and frontotemporal dementia
evidence.authors: Hilary C Archbold, Katherine L Jackson, An-chi Arora, Katherine Weskamp, Emily M Tank, Xuan Li, Sami J Barmada
evidence.relevant_quote: ...we find overexpression of XPO1, XPO7 and NXF1 are each sufficient to promote nuclear TDP43 egress. Taken together, our results indicate that redundant pathways regulate TDP43 nuclear export...

evidence.paper_title: Nuclear RNA binding regulates TDP-43 nuclear localization and passive nuclear export
evidence.authors: Lauren Duan, Benjamin L Zaepfel, Vasilisa Aksenova, Mary Dasso, Jeffrey D Rothstein, Petr Kalab, Lindsey R Hayes
evidence.relevant_quote: Here, we show that TDP-43 exits nuclei by passive diffusion, independent of facilitated mRNA export.

mechanism: Exportin 1 (XPO1), a major nuclear export receptor, recognizes and binds to proteins containing a leucine-rich nuclear export signal (NES), mediating their transport from the nucleus to the cytoplasm.
effect: The nuclear export of TDP-43 is facilitated, contributing to the cytoplasmic pool of the protein, though this pathway is considered redundant.
summary: TDP43 activates XPO1 to modulate tdp-43 nuclear export, ultimately affecting increased risk of aggregation & cellular toxicity.
